tgt_text.6235: Je ne vous savais pas si superbes.phédria.
tgt_text.6237: Écoutez-moi d’abord un moment tous deux.
tgt_text.6238: Quand vous aurez entendu ce que j’ai à vous dire, vous agirez à votre guise.phédria.
tgt_text.6240: Vous, éloignez-vous un peu de ce côté, seigneur Thrason.
tgt_text.6242: Pour commencer, il est une chose dont je désire vivement que vous soyez convaincus :
tgt_text.6243: c’est qu’en plaidant sa cause c’est surtout la mienne que j’entends servir.
tgt_text.6244: Et si vous y trouvez vous-mêmes votre compte, vous feriez une folie de ne pas en profiter.phédria.
tgt_text.6246: Mon avis est que vous devez accueillir votre rival le capitaine.chéréa.
tgt_text.6249: Phédria, il vous accommode, n’est-il pas vrai?
tgt_text.6251: il vous accommode d’y vivre bien.
tgt_text.6252: Vous n’avez que peu à lui donner, et il faut beaucoup à Thaïs pour suffire à vos amours sans que vous y mettiez du vôtre.
tgt_text.6253: Or, à tous ces points de vue, quelqu'un peut-il vous être plus avantageux, plus utile que lui?
tgt_text.6255: D’abordil a les moyens de donner, et nul ne le fait avec plus de largesse.
tgt_text.6259: il ronfle la nuit, il ronfle le jour.
tgt_text.6260: Vous n’avez pas à craindre qu’une femme en devienne amoureuse.
tgt_text.6261: Vous l’enverrez promener quand il vous plaira.phédria, à son frère.
tgt_text.6263: En outre il a une qualité que, pour ma part, je mets au-dessus de toutes :
tgt_text.6264: quand il s’agit de recevoir du monde à dîner, personne ne fait mieux et plus magnifiquement les choses.chéréa.
tgt_text.6265: Je serais bien étonné si, d’une façon ou d'une autre, nous ne tirions parti d’un tel homme.phédria.
tgt_text.6268: J'ai encore une gràce à obtenir de vous, c’est d’être reçu moi-même en votre compagnie.

tgt_text.6290: Elle eut quatre représentations, et elle fut donnée sous le consulat de C. Fannius et de M. Valérius.LE PROLOGUE.DÉMIPHON, frère de Chrémès et père d’Antiphon.CHRÉMÈS, frère de Démiphon et père de Phédria.

tgt_text.6294: Le frère de Chrémès, Démiphon, s’était absenté pour un voyage, en laissant A Athènes son fils Antiphon.
tgt_text.6295: Chrémès avait secrètement à Lemnos une femme et une fille, en même temps qu’à Athènes demeurait son autre épouse avec son fils, passionnément épris d’une / joueuse d’instruments.
tgt_text.6296: La mère qui était à Lemnos quitte cette Ile pour venir à Athènes.

tgt_text.6305: Phédria s’est épris d’une esclave musicienne, qu’il n’a pas le moyen de racheter.

tgt_text.6312: Il a aussi avec lui Géta, un domestique de son père, qui avait été laissé auprès des deux jeunes gens comme une espèce de gouverneur, mais qui s’est bientôt mis à leur entière discrétion.A son retour Démiphon a été furieux du mariage de son fils.

tgt_text.7983: PERSONNAGES MUETScallidie, esclave enlevée par Eschine.pamphila, fille de Sostrata, maîtresse d'Eschine.La scène se passe à Athènes,déméa, père de deux jeunes gens, a donné Eschine, à titre de fils adoptif, à son frère Micion;
tgt_text.7985: Ce dernier, épris de la beauté d’une musicienne, est soutenu contre la dureté et les rigueurs paternelles par Eschine, qui le cache, qui se fait passer pour l’amant, et qui finit par enlever la fille au marchand d’esclaves.
tgt_text.7986: Lui-mème il avait séduit une jeune citoyenne athénienne sans fortune, et il lui avait promis de l’épouser.

tgt_text.7988: Bientôt cependant, lorsque la vérité se découvre, Eschine épouse celle qu’il a séduite, et Ctésiphon obtient sa musicienne.Micion et Déméa, bourgeois d’Athènes, sont frères.
tgt_text.7989: Micion, homme d’un caractère indulgent, est célibataire, citadin;

tgt_text.7992: il vit de privations, et il impose l'existence la plus dure à tout ce qui l’entoure.
tgt_text.7994: Le plus jeune, Ctésiphon, est élevé par loi et ne le quitte point.
tgt_text.7995: Quant à l’atné, Eschine, l’autre vieillard l’a adopté, et s’est chargé de son éducation.
tgt_text.7996: Eschine, à qui l’indulgence de son père adoptif laisse une liberté absolue, entretient un commerce secret avec la ieune Pamphila.
tgt_text.7997: De son côté, Ctésiphon est moins amateur de la vie campagnarde que ne le pense son père.
tgt_text.7998: Il s'est lui-même passionné pour la chanteuse Callidie, que, dans une de ses excursions furtives à la ville, il a vue chez un marchand d’esclaves.
tgt_text.7999: L’ardent et impétueux Eschine vient en aide aux amours de son frère, parce qu’il le voit timide et peu entreprenant.
tgt_text.8000: Il enlève de force an marchand d’esclaves la maîtresse de Ctésiphon;
tgt_text.8001: et il la recueille chez lui, dans la maison de son père adoptif, où il ménage à son frère les moyens de la voir.
tgt_text.8002: Déméa, instruit par la rumeur publique du scandale qn’Eschine a causé, ne manque pas de jeter les hauts cris contre la faiblesse de Micion et contre les désordres du jeune homme.

tgt_text.8006: Déméa, du reste, n’est pas le seul à penser qu’Eschine ait enlevé la chanteuse pour son propre compte.

tgt_text.8011: D’abord, le malicieux Syrus le fait courir d’un bout de la ville à l’autre, tantôt après Ctésiphon, tantôt après Micion;
tgt_text.8012: pendant ce temps, l’esclave rusé aguerrit Ctésiphon contre son père;

tgt_text.8014: Ensuite, quand Déméa revient harassé de fatigue, et qu’il entre, sans être attendu, au logis de son frère, il y trouve la chanteuse et le Jeune homme.

tgt_text.9384: Les hommes, Déméa, présentent un grand nombre de signes caractéristiques, d’après lesquels, deux individus tenant la même conduite, il est facile de se prononcer, et, bien souvent, de dire :

tgt_text.12672: Tout ce dialogue est accompagné d’une pantomime significative.
tgt_text.12673: Les propositions de Déméa sont appuyées par les gestes suppliants d’Eschine, et c'est toujours sur les instances de ce dernier que cède Micion :
tgt_text.12674: il tiendrait peutêtre tété à son frère, mais il ne sait rien refuser à son fils adoptif.

tgt_text.12678: celui-ci est l’héritier direct de Micion, et c’est son héritage à venir que toutes ces largesses diminuent.— L. antépénultième.
tgt_text.12684: Cet échange de demandes et de réponses se trouve reproduit fidèlement par la dernière image que le manuscrit consacre aux Adelphes, A droite, Micion montre de la main Syrus, élève un peu les épaules d'un air de mépris, et semble bien dire :
tgt_text.12686: » A côté de Micion, Eschine incline la tête vers lui d'un air de commisération.
tgt_text.12687: Déméa, regardant son frère, tient la main droite élevée au-dessus de la tête de Syrus comme pour le prendre sous sa protection, et Syrus, un peu courbé sous cette main, ouvre les bras en portant son regard du côté de Micion.P. 604, l. 16.
tgt_text.12689: Déméa donne ainsi à la phrase de Micion un développement auquel celui-ci ne s'attendait pas.P. 606, l. avant-dernière.
tgt_text.12691: Remarquons bien que Déméa ne dit pas :
tgt_text.12693: » Il faut se garder de rien préciser qui puisse indiquer un mariage légal.
tgt_text.12694: Ce sera une de ces liaisons irrégulières dont nous avons vu un exemple dans l’Eunuque.
tgt_text.12695: Comme Phédria fait ménage avec la courtisane Thaïs, ménage où ils admettent en tiers le Thrason, de même Ctésiphon pense vivre avec la musicienne.
tgt_text.12696: Mais ce ne sera pas une liaison qui se puisse avouer au même titre que celle de son frère avec Pamphila.
tgt_text.12697: Les droits de la femme libre, de la citoyenne sont toujours respectés, et assurent constamment à celle-ci une condition meilleure, une condition régulière.
tgt_text.12698: Dans les notes que nous avons consacrées aux précédentes comédies nous nous sommes abstenu de porter un jugement sur l'ensemble et la portée d’aucune pièce de notre auteur.
tgt_text.12699: Mais il nous est impossible de ne pas émettre notre opinion sur celle-ci, que l'on regarde comme la plus remarquable de Térence.
tgt_text.12700: Examinée sous le rapport du caractère des deux principaux personnages, des déni frères les vieillards, ou bien sous le rapport du dénouaient, elle manque de toutes les conditions que nous réclamerions aujourd'hui, disons mieux, de toutes les conditions essentielles d’une bonne comédie pour la première œuvre dramatique venue.
tgt_text.12701: II s’opère dans le rôle des deux vieillards un revirement, qu’on nous pardonne le mot, un revirement inadmissible, et dont la portée est tout à fait nulle.
tgt_text.12702: Les générosités ridicules du vieux grondeur n’ont aucun mérite, puisqu'elles ne lui coûtent pas une obole, et de plus elles n’ont rien de plaisant.
tgt_text.12703: Il se pose à la fin en père éclairé et sage, sans que rien l’autorise à prétendre à ce titre.
tgt_text.12704: D’autre part, l’honnéte et sage Micion est gratuitement voué au ridicule, et il donne sans la moindre nécessité un démenti complet à tous ses actes antérieurs.
tgt_text.12705: Il en ré sulte que l’un et l'autre deviennent des personnages manqués et indignes également de notre intérêt.
tgt_text.12706: Pour ce qui est du dénoûment, il n’est pas moins défectueux.
tgt_text.12707: C’est Déméa qui ratifie le mariage d’Eschine :
tgt_text.12709: N’est-ce pas le père adoptif qui devrait intervenir et directement et seul.
tgt_text.12710: Ensuite, n’est-il pas scandaleux que ce soit le moraliste rigoureux et intolérant qui autorise les amours de son fils et d’une musicienne par lui conspuée?
tgt_text.12711: Enfin, et ce reproche, qui tient du reste à toutes les fautes que nous signalons ici, ce reproche, disons-nous, est le plus grave :
tgt_text.12712: la pièce manque absolument d’ensemble et de portée.
tgt_text.12713: Elle n’est pas « une » le moins du monde, et il y a violalion d’un des premiers principes de l’art sérieux :
tgt_text.12715: quelle satisfaction accorde-t-elle, soit aux sympathies, soit au bon sens du spectateur ou du lecteur?
tgt_text.12717: il faut bien le dire.Et qu’on ne se le dissimule pas :
tgt_text.12718: il en est à peu près ainsi des cinq autres pièces.
tgt_text.12719: Assurément le génie comique, et même le génie, dans l’acception générale du mot, manquaient à Térence;
tgt_text.12720: ou du moins sa constante habitude de se traîner sur les pas de la comédie grecque l’a empêché de produire une œuvre vraiment belle, complètement belle.
tgt_text.12721: Il n’est, bien décidément, qu’un demi-Ménandre, comme l’appelle Jules César, qu’un demi-comique.
tgt_text.12722: Dira-t-on, pour cela, que Plaute soit le comique complet?
tgt_text.12724: les préjugés modernes, nos mœurs, nos scrupules, tout enfin s’oppose à ce que la palme soit accordée à Plaute, bien qu’il soit autrement ingénieux que Térence et que sa lecture soit souvent bien intéressante et bien curieuse.
tgt_text.12725: Mais l’idéal, que ni Térence ni Plaute ne sauraient réaliser, nous le possédons, grâce au ciel, puisque nous possédons Molière.FIN DES NOTES DES ADELPHES

tgt_text.130: Chremes going to Asia, leaves his daughter, Pasibula, in the care of his brother Phania, who, afterwards setting sail with Pasibula for Asia, is wrecked off the Isle of Andros.
tgt_text.131: Escaping with their lives, they are kindly received by a native of the island;
tgt_text.132: and Phania soon afterwards dies there.
tgt_text.133: The Andrian changes the name of the girl to Glycerium, and brings her up, as his own child, with his daughter Chrysis.
tgt_text.134: On his death, Chrysis and Glycerium sail for Athens to seek their fortune there.
tgt_text.135: Chrysis being admired by several Athenian youths, Pam­ philus, the son of Simo, an opulent citizen, chances to see Glycerium, and falls violently in love with her.
tgt_text.136: She afterwards becomes preg­ nant by him, on which he makes her a promise of marriage.
tgt_text.137: In the meantime, Chremes, who is now living at Athens, and is ignorant of the fate of Pasibula, agrees with Simo, the father of Pamphilus, to give Philumena, another daughter, in marriage to Pamphilus.
tgt_text.138: While these arrangements are being made, Chrysis dies;
tgt_text.139: on which Simo accidentally discovers his son's connexion with Glycerium.
tgt_text.140: Chremes, also coming to hear of it, declines the match, having no idea that Glycerium is really his own daughter.
tgt_text.141: Simo, however, in order to test his son's feelings, resolves to pretend that the marriage- day is fixed.
tgt_text.142: Meeting Pamphilus in the town, he desires him to go home and prepare for the wedding, which is to take place imme­ diately.
tgt_text.143: In his perplexity, the youth has recourse to his servant Davus, who, having heard of the refusal of Chremes, suspects the design of Simo.
tgt_text.144: At this conjuncture, Charinus, a friend of Pamphilus, who is enamoured of Philumena, but has been rejected by her father, entreats Pamphilus to put off the marriage, for at least a few days.
tgt_text.145: Disclosing his own aversion to the match, Pamphilus readily engages to do this.
tgt_text.146: In order the more effectually to break it off, Davus advises Pamphilus to pretend a readiness to comply with his father's wishes, supposing that of course Chremes will steadily persist in his refusal.
tgt_text.147: Pamphilus does as he is advised, on which Simo again applies to Chremes, who, after some entreaty, gives his consent.
tgt_text.148: Just at this conjuncture, Glycerium is delivered of a son;
tgt_text.149: and by the advice of Davus, it is laid before the door of Simo's house.
tgt_text.150: Chremes hap­ pening to see it there, and ascertaining that Pamphilus is its father, again refuses to give him his daughter.
tgt_text.151: At this moment, Crito, a native of Andros, arrives, who, being a relative of Chrysis, has come to Athens to look after her property.
tgt_text.153: Chremes dis- covers that Glycerium is no other than his long-lost daughter, Pasibula;
tgt_text.154: on which he consents to her immediate marriage with Pamphilus, who promises Charinus that he will use his best endea- vours to obtain for him the hand of Philumena.

tgt_text.2433: A CERTAIN citizen of Athens had a daughter named Pamphila, and a son called Chremes.
tgt_text.2434: The former was stolen while an infant, and sold to a Rhodian merchant, who having made a present of her to a Courtesan of Rhodes, she brought her up with her own daughter Thais, who was somewhat older.
tgt_text.2435: In the course of years, Thais following her mother's way of life, removes to Athens.
tgt_text.2436: Her mother dying, her property is put up for sale, and Pamphila is purchased as a slave by Thraso, an officer and an admirer of Thais, who happens just then to be visiting Rhodes.
tgt_text.2437: During the absence of Thraso, Thais becomes acquainted with Phædria, an Athenian youth, the son of Laches;
tgt_text.2438: she also dis­ covers from Chremes, who lives near Athens, that Pamphila, her former companion, is his sister.
tgt_text.2439: Thraso returns, intending to present to her the girl he has bought, but determines not to do so until she has discarded Phædria.
tgt_text.2440: Finding that the girl is no other than Pam­ phila, Thais is at a loss what to do, as she both loves Phædria, and is extremely anxious to recover Pamphila.
tgt_text.2441: At length, to please the Captain, she excludes Phædria, but next day sends for him, and explains to him her reasons, at the same time begging of him to allow Thraso the sole right of admission to her house for the next two days, and assuring him that as soon as she shall have gained pos­ session of the girl, she will entirely throw him off.
tgt_text.2442: Phædria consents, and resolves to spend these two days in the country;
tgt_text.2443: at the same time he orders Parmeno to take to Thais a Eunuch and an Æthiopian girl, whom he has purchased for her.
tgt_text.2444: The Captain also sends Pam­ phila, who is accidentally seen by Chaerea, the younger brother ot Phædria;
tgt_text.2445: he, being smitten with her beauty, prevails upon Parmeno to introduce him into the house of Thais, in the Eunuch's dress.
tgt_text.2446: Being admitted there, in the absence of Thais, he ravishes the damsel.
tgt_text.2447: Shortly afterwards Thraso quarrels with Thais, and comes with all his attendants to her house to demand the return of Pam­ phila, but is disappointed.
tgt_text.2448: In conclusion, Pamphila is recognized by her brother Chremes, and is promised in marriage to Chærea;
tgt_text.2449: while Thraso becomes reconciled to Phædria, through the mediation of Gnatho, his Parasite.

tgt_text.4914: CHREMES,1 an old gentleman, living in the country.
tgt_text.4915: MENEDEMUS, an old gentleman, his neighbour.
tgt_text.4918: ANTIPHILA,8 a young woman beloved by Clinia.
tgt_text.4923: before the houses of CHREMES and MENEDEMUS.CHREMES commands his wife, when pregnant, if she is delivered of a girl immediately to kill the child.
tgt_text.4924: Having given birth to a girl, Sostrata delivers her to an old woman named Philtera to be exposed.
tgt_text.4925: Instead of doing this, Philtera calls her Antiphila, and brings her up as her own.
tgt_text.4926: Clinia, the son of Menedemus, falls in love with her, and treats her as though his wife.
tgt_text.4927: Menedemus, on learning this, is very angry, and by his harsh language drives away his son from home.
tgt_text.4928: Taking this to heart, and in order to punish himself for his ill-timed severity, Menedemus, though now an aged man, fatigues himself by labouring at agricultural pursuits from morning till night.
tgt_text.4929: At the period when the Play commences, Clinia has 'ust returned to Attica, but not daring to go to his father's house, is entertained by Clitipho, the son of Chremes, who is the neighbour ot Menedemus.
tgt_text.4930: Clitipho then sends for Antiphila, whose supposed mother has recently died, to come and meet her lover.
tgt_text.4931: On the same day, Chremes learns from Menedemus how anxious he is for his son's return;
tgt_text.4932: and on hearing from his son of the arrival of Clinia, he defers informing Menedemus of it until the next day.
tgt_text.4933: Syrus, the servant who has been sent to fetch Antiphila, also brings with him Bacchis, an extravagant Courtesan, the mistress of Clitipho.
tgt_text.4934: To conceal the truth from Chremes, they represent to him that Bacchis is the mistress of Clinia, and that Antiphila is one of her maids.
tgt_text.4935: Next morning Chremesinforms Mene­ demus of his son's arrival, and of the extravagant conduct of his mistress, but begs that he will conceal from Clinia his knowledge ot this fact.
tgt_text.4936: Bacchis requiring ten minæ, Syrus devises a plan for obtain­ ing the money from Chremes, while the latter is encouraging him to think of a project against Menedemus.
tgt_text.4937: Syrus tells him a story, that the mother of Antiphila had borrowed a thousand drachmae of Bacchis, and being dead, the girl is left in her hands as a pledge for the money.
tgt_text.4938: While these things are going on, Sostrata discovers in Antiphila her own daughter.
tgt_text.4939: In order to obtain the money which Bacchis persists in demanding, Syrus suggests to Chremes that it should be represented to Menedemus that Bacchis is the mistress of Clitipho, and that he should be requested to conceal her in his house for a few days;
tgt_text.4940: it is also arranged that Clinia shall pretend to his father to be in love with Antiphila, and to beg her as his wife.
tgt_text.4941: He is then to ask for money, as though for the wedding, which is to be handed over to Bacchis.
tgt_text.4942: Chremes does not at first approve of the plan suggested by Syrus;
tgt_text.4943: but he pays down the money for which he has been informed his daughter is a pledge in the hands of Bacchis.
tgt_text.4944: This, with his knowledge, is given to Clitipho, who, as Syrus says, is to convey it to Bacchis, who is now in the house of Menedemus, to make the latter more readily believe that she is his mistress.
tgt_text.4945: Shortly after this, the plot is dis­ covered by Chremes, who threatens to punish Clitipho and Syrus.
tgt_text.4946: The Play concludes with Chremes giving his consent to the marriage of Clinia with Antiphila, and pardoning Clitipho, who promises to abandon the Courtesan, and marry.
tgt_text.4947: Unlike the other Plays ot Terence and Plautus, the plot of this Play extends over two days.

tgt_text.7161: MICIO,2HEGIO,3 an aged Athenian, kinsman of Sostrata.
tgt_text.7162: ÆSCHINUS,4 son of Demea, adopted by Micio.
tgt_text.7164: PAMPHILA,11 a young woman beloved by Æschinus.
tgt_text.7168: before the houses of MICIO and SOSTRATA.
tgt_text.7169: MICIO and DEMEA are two brothers of dissimilar tempers.
tgt_text.7170: Demea is married, and lives a country life, while his brother remains single, and resides in Athens.
tgt_text.7171: Demea has two sons, the elder of whom, Æschinus, has been adopted by Micio.
tgt_text.7172: Being allowed by his indulgent uncle to gratify his inclinations without restraint, Æschinus has de­ bauched Pamphila, the daughter of a widow named Sostrata.
tgt_text.7173: Having, however, promised to marry the young woman, he has been pardoned for the offence, and it has been kept strictly secret.
tgt_text.7174: Ctesipho, who lives in the country with his father under great restraint, on visiting the city, falls in love with a certain Music-girl, who belongs to the Procurer Sannio.
tgt_text.7175: To screen his brother, Æschinus takes the respon­ sibility of the affair on himself, and succeeds in carrying off the girl for him.
tgt_text.7176: Demea, upon hearing of this, censures Micio for his ill- timed indulgence, the bad effects of which are thus exemplified in Æschinus;
tgt_text.7177: and at the same time lauds the steady conduct and fruga­ lity of Ctesipho, who has been brought up under his own supervision.
tgt_text.7178: Shortly after this, Sostrata hears the story about the Music-girl, at the very time that her daughter Pamphila is in labour.
tgt_text.7179: She naturally supposes that Æschinus has deserted her daughter for another, and hastens to acquaint Hegio, her kinsman, with the fact.
tgt_text.7180: Meantime Demea learns that Ctesipho has taken part in carrying off the Music- girl, whereon Syrus invents a story, and screens Ctesipho for the mo­ ment.
tgt_text.7181: Demea is next informed by Hegio of the conduct of Æschinus towards Pamphila.
tgt_text.7182: Wishing to find his brother, he is purposely sent on a fruitless errand by Syrus, on which he wanders all over the city to no purpose.
tgt_text.7183: Micio having now been informed by Hegio, and knowing that the intentions of Æschinus towards Pamphila are not changed, accompanies him to the house of Sostrata, whom he consoles by his promise that Æschinus shall marry her daughter.
tgt_text.7184: Demea then returns from his search, and, rushing into Micio's house, finds his son Ctesipho there carousing;
tgt_text.7185: on which he exclaims vehe­ mently against Micio, who uses his best endeavours to soothe him, and finally with success.
tgt_text.7186: He now determines to become kind and consi­ derate for the future.
tgt_text.7187: At his request, Pamphila is brought to Micio's house, and the nuptials are celebrated.
tgt_text.7188: Micio, at the earnest request of Demea and Æschinus, marries Sostrata;
tgt_text.7189: Hegio has a competency allowed him;
tgt_text.7190: and Syrus and his wife Phrygia are made flee.
tgt_text.7191: The Play concludes with a serious warning from Demea, who advises his relatives not to squander their means in riotous living;
tgt_text.7192: but, on the contrary, to bear admonition and to submit to restraint in a spirit of moderation and thankfulness.

tgt_text.9237: Meantime, however, he is suddenly called away from home.
tgt_text.9238: During his absence, Philumena, finding herself pregnant in consequence of her misfortune before her marriage, fearing detection, especially avoids the company of her mother-in-law.
tgt_text.9239: At length she makes an excuse for returning to the home of her own parents, where she remains.

tgt_text.10195: I, Pamphilus, could really wish, if it were possible, this alliance between us to be lasting;
tgt_text.10196: but if you are other­ wise inclined, still take the child.
tgt_text.10198: He has discovered that she has been brought to bed.
tgt_text.10204: We have had a grandson born to us;
tgt_text.10205: for my daughter was removed from you in a state of pregnancy, and yet never before this day did I know that she was pregnant.
tgt_text.10207: So may the Gods prosper me, you bring good tidings, and I am glad a child has been born, and that she is safe:
tgt_text.10208: but what kind of woman have you for a wife, or of what sort of a temper, that we should have been kept in ignorance of this so long ?
tgt_text.10209: I cannot sufficiently express how disgraceful this conduct appears to me.
tgt_text.10211: This conduct does not vex me less than yourself, Laches.PAM. (aside.)
tgt_text.10212: Even if it had just now been a matter of doubt to me, it is so no longer, since the child of another man is to accompany her.
tgt_text.10214: Pamphilus, there is no room now for deliberation for you in this matter.
tgt_text.10218: We were often longing to see the day on which there should be one to call you father;
tgt_text.10220: I return thanks to the Gods.PAM. (aside.)
tgt_text.10223: Take home your wife, and don't oppose my will.
tgt_text.10225: Father, if she had wished to have children by me, or to continue to be my wife, I am quite certain she would not have concealed from me what I find she has concealed.
tgt_text.10226: Now, as I find that her mind is estranged from TIle, and think that there would be no agreement between us in future, why should I take her back ?
tgt_text.10228: The young woman has done what her mother per­ suaded her.
tgt_text.10229: Is that to be wondered at ?
tgt_text.10230: Do you suppose you can find any woman who is free from fault ?
tgt_text.10231: Or is it that men have no failings ?
tgt_text.10233: Do you yourselves now consider, Laches, and you, Pamphilus, whether it is most advisable for you to leave her or take her back.
tgt_text.10234: What your wife may do, is not in my control.
tgt_text.10235: Under neither circumstance will you meet with any difficulty from me.
tgt_text.10236: But what are we to do with the child?
tgt_text.10238: You do ask an absurd question;
tgt_text.10239: whatever happens, send him back his child of course, that we may bring it up as ours.
tgt_text.10241: A child which the father has aban­ doned, am I to rear ?
tgt_text.10245: Prithee, are we to expose it, in preference ?
tgt_text.10247: Really, I cannot now be silent any longer.
tgt_text.10248: For you force me to say in his presence (pointing to PHI­ DIPPUS) what I would rather not.
tgt_text.10249: Do you suppose I am in ignorance of the cause of your tears, or what it is on account of which you are perplexed to this degree ?
tgt_text.10250: In the first place, when you alleged as a reason, that, on account of your mother, you could not have your wife at home, she promised that she would leave the house.
tgt_text.10251: Now, since you see this pretext as well taken away from you, because a child has been born without your knowledge, you have got another.
tgt_text.10252: You are mistaken if you suppose that I am ignorant of your feelings.
tgt_text.10253: That at last you might prevail upon your feelings to take this step, how long a period for loving a mistress did I allow you !
tgt_text.10254: With what patience did I bear the expense you were at in keeping her!
tgt_text.10255: I remonstrated with you and entreated you to take a wife.
tgt_text.10256: I said that it was time:
tgt_text.10258: What you then did in obedience to me, you did as became you.
tgt_text.10259: Now again you have set your fancy upon a mistress, and, to gratify her, you do an injury to the other as well.
tgt_text.10260: For I see plainly that you have once more relapsed into the same course of life.
tgt_text.10263: Your own self, and you act unjustly therein.
tgt_text.10264: You feign false grounds for discord, that you may live with her when you have got rid of this witness of your actions;
tgt_text.10265: your wife has perceived it too;
tgt_text.10266: for what other reason had she for leaving you ?
tgt_text.10271: I will give you my oath that none of these is the reason.
tgt_text.10273: Oh take home your wife, or tell me why you should not.
tgt_text.10275: It is not the time at present.
tgt_text.10277: Take the child, for surely that is not in fault;
tgt_text.10278: I will consider about the mother afterwards.
tgt_text.10280: In every way I am wretched, and what to do I know not;
tgt_text.10281: with so many troubles is my father now besetting wretched me on every side.
tgt_text.10282: I'll go away from here, since I avail but little by my presence.
tgt_text.10283: For without my consent, I do not believe that they will bring up the child, especially as on that point my mother-in-law will second me.
tgt_text.10287: What, and give me no distinct answer ?
tgt_text.10290: to you to be in his senses ?
tgt_text.10296: No wonder if my wife has taken this amiss:
tgt_text.10298: they do not easily put up with such things.
tgt_text.10299: Hence that anger of hers, for she herself told me of it;
tgt_text.10300: I would not mention this to you in his presence, and at first I did not believe her;
tgt_text.10301: but now it is true beyond a doubt;
tgt_text.10302: for I see that his feelings are alto­ gether averse to marriage.
tgt_text.10304: What am I to do, then, Phidippus ?
tgt_text.10308: I am of opinion that first we ought to go to this mistress of his.
tgt_text.10309: Let us use entreaties with her;
tgt_text.10311: and at last, let us very seriously threaten her, if she gives him any encouragement in future.
tgt_text.10313: I will do as you advise.
tgt_text.10314: (Turning to an ATTENDANT) Ho, there, boy!
tgt_text.10315: run to the house of Bacchis here, our neigh­ bour;
tgt_text.10316: desire her, in my name, to come hither.
tgt_text.10318: And you, I further entreat, to give me your assistance in this affair.
tgt_text.10320: Well, I have already said, and I now say again to the same effect, Laches, I wish this alliance between us to continue, if by any means it possibly may, which I trust will be the case.
tgt_text.10321: But should you like1 me to be with you while you meet her ?
tgt_text.10324: but first go and get some one as a nurse for the child.
tgt_text.10327: It is not for nothing that Laches now desires to speak with me;
tgt_text.10328: and, i'faith, I am not very far from mistaken in making a guess what it is he wants me for.
tgt_text.10330: I must take care that I don't, through anger, miss gaining in this quarter what I otherwise might, and that I don't do anything which hereafter it would have been better I had not done.
tgt_text.10337: Troth, now, Bacchis, I suppose you somewhat wonder what can be my reason for sending the lad to fetch you out of doors.
tgt_text.10339: Upon my faith, I am even in some anxiety as well, when I reflect what I am, lest the name of my calling should be to my prejudice;
tgt_text.10340: for my behaviour I can easily defend.
tgt_text.10342: If you speak the truth, you will be in no danger, woman, from me, for I am now of that age that it is not meet for me to receive forgiveness for a fault;
tgt_text.10343: for that reason do I the more carefully attend to every particular, that I may not act with rashness;
tgt_text.10344: for if you now do, or intend to do, that which is proper for deserving women to do, it would be unjust for me, in my ignorance, to offer an injury to you, when undeserving of it.
tgt_text.10346: On my word, great is the gratitude that I ought to feel towards you for such conduct;
tgt_text.10347: for he who, after commit­ ting an injury, would excuse himself, would profit me but little.
tgt_text.10350: You admit my son, Pamphilus, to your house.
tgt_text.10355: before he was married to this woman, I tolerated your amour.
tgt_text.10357: I have not yet said to you what I intended.
tgt_text.10358: He has now got a wife:
tgt_text.10359: look out for another person more to be depended on, while you have time to deliberate;
tgt_text.10360: for neither will he be of this mind all his life, nor, i' faith, will you be always of your present age.
tgt_text.10369: and she has taken away her daughter;
tgt_text.10370: and for that reason, has wished secretly to destroy the child that has been born.
tgt_text.10372: Did I know any other means whereby I might be enabled to establish my credit with you, more solemn than an oath, I would, Laches, assure you of this, that I have kept Pamphilus at a distance1 from me ever since he took a wife.
tgt_text.10375: But, pray, do you know what I would prefer that you should do ?
tgt_text.10380: Go in-doors there (pointing to the house of PHIDIP­ PUS) to the women, and make the same promise, on oath, to them;
tgt_text.10381: satisfy their minds, and clear yourself from this charge.
tgt_text.10384: although, i’ faith, if it had been any other woman of this calling, she would not have done so, 1 am quite sure;
tgt_text.10385: present herself before a married woman for such a purpose!
tgt_text.10386: But I do not wish your son to be suspected on an unfounded report, nor appear inconstant, undeservedly, to you, to whom he by no means ought ;
tgt_text.10387: for he has deserved of me, that so far as I am able, I should do him a service.
tgt_text.10389: Your language has rendered me quite friendly and well disposed towards you;
tgt_text.10390: but not only did they think so—I too believed it.
tgt_text.10391: Now that I have found you quite different from what I had expected, take care that you still continue the same-make use of my friendship as yuu please;
tgt_text.10393: but I will forbear, that you may not hear anything unkind from me.
tgt_text.10394: But this one thing I recommend you—make trial what sort of a friend I am, or what I can effect as such, rather than what as an enemy.
tgt_text.10396: Nothing at my house will I suffer you to be in want of;
tgt_text.10397: but whatever is requisite shall be supplied you in abundance.
tgt_text.10398: Still, when you are well fed and well drenched, do take care that the child has enough.
tgt_text.10399: (The NURSE goes into his house.)LACH. (to BACCHIS.)
tgt_text.10400: My son's father-in-law, I see, is coming;
tgt_text.10401: he is bringing a nurse for the child.
tgt_text.10409: Upon my faith, those women don't fear the Gods;
tgt_text.10410: and I don't think that the Gods care about them.
tgt_text.10412: I will give you up my female servants;
tgt_text.10413: with my full permission, examine them with any tortures you please.
tgt_text.10414: The business at present is this :
tgt_text.10415: I must make his wife return home to Pamphilus;
tgt_text.10416: should I effect that, I shall not regret its being reported that I have been the only one to do what other courtesans avoid doing.
tgt_text.10418: We find, Phidippus, that our wives have been unjustly suspected2 by us in this matter.
tgt_text.10419: Let us now try her still further;
tgt_text.10420: for if your wife discovers that she has given credence to a false charge, she will dismiss her resent­ ment ;
tgt_text.10421: but if my son is also angry, by reason of the circum­ stance that his wife has been brought to bed without his knowledge, that is a trifle:
tgt_text.10422: his anger on that account will speedily subside.
tgt_text.10423: Assuredly in this matter, there is nothing so bad as to be deserving of a separation.
tgt_text.10425: I sincerely wish it may be so.
tgt_text.10431: Why do you tell me these things ?
tgt_text.10432: Is it because you have not already heard what my feelings are with regard to this matter, Laches ?
tgt_text.10433: Do you only satisfy their minds.
tgt_text.10435: Troth now, Bacchis, I do entreat that what you have promised me you will do.
tgt_text.10437: Would you wish me, then, to go in about this business ?
tgt_text.10439: Go, and satisfy their minds, so as to make them believe it.
tgt_text.10442: although, upon my word, I am quite sure that my presence will be disagreeable to them, for a married woman is the enemy of a mistress, when she has been sepa­ rated from her husband.
tgt_text.10444: But they will be your friends, when they know the reason of your coming.
tgt_text.10446: And I promise that they shall be your friends, when they know the fact;
tgt_text.10447: for you will release them from their mistake, and yourself, at the same time, from suspicion.
tgt_text.10452: Do you both follow me into the house.
tgt_text.10453: (Goes into the house with PHIDIPPUS and her ATTENDANTS.)LACH. (to himself.)
tgt_text.10454: What is there that I could more wish for, than what I see has happened to this woman ?
tgt_text.10455: To gain favour without loss to myself, and to benefit myself at the same time.
tgt_text.10456: For if now it is the fact that she has really with­ drawn from Pamphilus, she knows that by that step she has acquired honour and reputation:
tgt_text.10457: she returns the favour to him, and, by the same means, attaches us as friends to her­ self.
tgt_text.10459: Upon my faith, my master does assuredly think my labour of little value ;
tgt_text.10460: to have sent me for nothing, where I have been sitting the whole day to no purpose, waiting at the citadel for Callidemides, his land­ lord at Myconos.
tgt_text.10461: And so, while sitting there to-day, like a fool, as each person came by, I accosted him:
tgt_text.10462: —“Young man, just tell me, pray, are you a Myconian ?" "I am not."
tgt_text.10463: u But is your name Callidemides ?” “No.” “ Have you any former guest here named Pamphilus ?"
tgt_text.10465: and I don't believe that there is any such person."
tgt_text.10466: At last, i'faith, I was quite ashamed, and went away.
tgt_text.10467: But how is it I see Bacchis coming out of our neighbour's ?
tgt_text.10468: What business can she have there ?
tgt_text.10470: Parmeno, you make your appearance opportunely;
tgt_text.10471: n with all speed1 to Pamphilus.
tgt_text.10475: Say that I entreat him to come.
tgt_text.10484: Am I to say nothing else ?
tgt_text.10487: that Myrrhina has recognised that ring as her daughter's, which he formerly gave me.
tgt_text.10492: He will be here directly he has heard this from you.
tgt_text.10496: for I've not had the opportunity given me to-day;
tgt_text.10497: so much with running and walking about have I wasted the whole day.
tgt_text.10499: What great joy have I caused for Pamphilus by my coming to-day!
tgt_text.10500: How many blessings have I brought him !
tgt_text.10501: and from how many sorrows have I rescued him!
tgt_text.10502: A son I save for him, when it was nearly perishing through the agency of these women and of himself:
tgt_text.10503: a wife, whom he thought that he must cast off for ever, I restore to him :
tgt_text.10504: from the suspicion that he lay under with his father and Phidippus, I have cleared him.
tgt_text.10505: This ring, in fact, was the cause of these discoveries being made.
tgt_text.10506: For I remember, that about ten months ago, at an early hour of night, he came running home to my house, out of breath, without a companion, and sur­ charged with wine,1 with this ring in his hand.
tgt_text.10508: “ My Pamphilus,” I said, “ prithee, my dear, why thus breathless, or where did you get thai ring ?—tell me!"
tgt_text.10509: He began to pretend that he was thinking of some­ thing else.
tgt_text.10510: When I saw that, I began to suspect I know not what, and to press him still more to tell me.
tgt_text.10511: The fellow con­ fessed that he had ravished some female, he knew not whom, in the street;
tgt_text.10512: and said, that while she was struggling, he had taken that ring away from her.
tgt_text.10513: Myrrhina here recognized it just now, while I had it on my finger.
tgt_text.10515: I told her all the story.
tgt_text.10516: Hence the discovery has been made, that it was Philumena ravished by him, and that this new-born child is his.
tgt_text.10517: I am overjoyed that this happiness has befallen him through my agency;
tgt_text.10518: although other courtesans would not have similar feelings ;
tgt_text.10519: nor, indeed, is it to our interest that any lover should find pleasure in matrimony.
tgt_text.10520: But, i' faith, I never, for the sake of gain, will give my mind to base actions.
tgt_text.10521: So long as I had the opportunity, I found him to be kind, easy, and good-natured.
tgt_text.10522: This marriage has fallen out unluckily for me,—that I confess to be the fact.
tgt_text.10523: But, upon my word, I do think that I have done nothing for it to befall me deservedly.
tgt_text.10524: It is but reasonable to endure inconveniences from one from whom I have received so many benefits.
tgt_text.10526: Once more, take care, will you, my dear Parmeno, that you have brought me a faithful and distinct account, so as not to allure me for a short time to indulge in these transient joys.
tgt_text.10534: I am quite a God, if it is so !
tgt_text.10539: I fear that I'm believing one thing, and you are telling another.
tgt_text.10543: I think you said to this effect—that Myrrhina had discovered that Bacchis has her ring.
tgt_text.10547: The one I formerly gave to her;
tgt_text.10548: and she has desired you to tell me this:
tgt_text.10551: Such is so, I tell you.
tgt_text.10553: Who is there happier than I, and, in fact, more full of joyousness?
tgt_text.10554: What am I to present you for these tidings ?
tgt_text.10563: for neither in the tidings nor in myself do I know of there being any advantage to you.
tgt_text.10566: am I to suffer you, who have caused me, when dead, to be restored from the shades to life-to leave me unrewarded ?
tgt_text.10567: Oh, you deem me too thankless!
tgt_text.10568: But look —I see Bacchis standing before the door;
tgt_text.10569: she's waiting for me, I suppose;
tgt_text.10576: It is a fortunate thing, and gives me great delight.
tgt_text.10578: By your actions, you give me reason to believe you, and so much do you retain your former charming qualities, that wherever you go, the meeting with you, your company, your conversation, always give pleasure.
tgt_text.10580: And you, upon my word, possess your former man­ ners and disposition;
tgt_text.10581: so much so that not a single man living is more engaging than you.
tgt_text.10586: You had reason, Pamphilus, for being so fond of your wife.
tgt_text.10587: For never before to-day did I set eyes upon her, so as to know her:
tgt_text.10588: she seems a very gentle person.
tgt_text.10592: So may the Gods bless me, Pamphilus!PAM.
tgt_text.10593: Tell me, have you as yet told any of these matters to my father ?
tgt_text.10597: Nor is there need, in fact;
tgt_text.10599: I don't wish it to be the case here as it is in the Comedies,1 where everything is known to everybody.
tgt_text.10600: Here, those who ought to know, know already;
tgt_text.10601: but those who ought not to know, shall neither hear of it nor know it.
tgt_text.10603: Nay more, I will give you a proof why you may suppose that this may be the more easily concealed.
tgt_text.10604: Myrrhina has told Phidippus to this effect—that she has given credit to my oath, and that, in consequence, in her eyes you are exculpated.
tgt_text.10607: and I trust that this matter will turn out according to our wishes.
tgt_text.10609: Master, may I not be allowed to know from you what is the good that I have done to-day, or what it is you are talking about ?
tgt_text.10613: Still I suspect. “ restore him, when dead, from the shades below."
tgt_text.10617: You don't know, Parmeno, how much you have benefited me to-day, and from what troubles you have extricated me.
tgt_text.10619: Nay, but indeed I do know:
tgt_text.10620: and I did not do it without design.
tgt_text.10624: Could Parmeno, from negligence, omit anything that ought to be done ?
tgt_text.10627: for my part, I have done more good to- day, without knowing it, than ever I did, knowingly, in all my life.
tgt_text.10631: CHREMES,2 ANTJPHO,3 son of Demipho.NAUSISTRATA,12 the wife of Chremes.
tgt_text.10635: before the houses of DEMIPHO, CHREMES, and DORTO.CHREMES and DEMIPHO are two aged Athenians, brothers.
tgt_text.10636: Nausistrats the wife of Chremes, is a wealthy woman, possessed of large estates ii.
tgt_text.10638: Chremes, who goes thither yearly to receive the rents, meets with a poor woman there, whom he secretly marries, and has by her a daughter, called Phanium :
tgt_text.10639: while engaged in this intrigue, Chremes passes at Lemnos by the name of Stilpho.
tgt_text.10640: By his wife, Nausistrata, at Athens, Chremes has a son, named Phædria, and his brother has a son, named Antipho.
tgt_text.10641: Phanium having now arrived at her fifteenth year, the two brothers privately agree that she shall be brought to Athens and married to Antipho.
tgt_text.10642: For this purpose, Chremes goes to Lemnos, while Demipho is obliged to take a journey to Cilicia.
tgt_text.10643: On departing, they leave their sons in the care of Geta, one of Demipho's servants.
tgt_text.10644: Shortly afterwards, Phædria falls in love with a Music-girl, but, from want of means, is unable to purchase her from her owner.
tgt_text.10645: In the meantime, the Lemnian wife of Chremes, urged by poverty, embarks for Athens, whither she arrives with her daughter and her nurse.
tgt_text.10646: Here they inquire for Stilpho, but in vain, as they cannot find any one of that name.
tgt_text.10647: Shortly after, the mother dies, and Antipho, seeing Phanium by acci­ dent.
tgt_text.10649: Being wishful to marry her, applies to Phormio, a Parasite, for his advice.
tgt_text.10650: The latter hits upon the fol­ lowing scheme:
tgt_text.10651: there being a law at Athens, which obliges the next- of-kin to female orphans, either to marry them or give them a portion, the Parasite pretends that he is a friend of Phanium, and insists that Antipho is her nearest relation, and is consequently bound to marry her.
tgt_text.10652: Antipho is summoned before a court of justice, and it being previously arranged, allows judgment to be given against himself, and immediately marries Phanium.
tgt_text.10653: Shortly after, the old men return upon the same day, and are much vexed, the one on finding that his son has married a woman without a fortune, the other that he has lost the opportunity of getting his daughter advantageously married.
tgt_text.10654: In the meantime, Phæedria being necessitated to raise some money to purchase the Music-girl, Geta and Pbormio arrange that the former shall pretend to the old man, that Phormio has consented to take back the woman whom Antipho has married, if Demipho will give her a portion of thirty minæ.
tgt_text.10655: Demipho borrows the money of Chremes, and pays it to Phormio, who hands it over to Phædria, and Phædria to Doric, for his mistress.
tgt_text.10656: At this conjuncture, it becomes known who Phanium really is, and the old men are delighted to find that Antipho has married the very person they wished.
tgt_text.10657: They attempt however, to get back the thirty minæ from Phormio, and proceed to threats and violence.
tgt_text.10658: On this, Phormio, who has accidentally learnt the intrigue of Chremes with the woman of Lemnos, exposes him, and relates the whole story to his wife, Nausistrata;
tgt_text.10659: on which she censures her husband for his bad conduct, and the Play concludes with her thanks to Phormio for his information,PERFORMED at the Roman Games,1 L. Posthumius Albinæ and L. Cornelius Merula being Curule Ædiles.
tgt_text.10660: L. Ambi­ vius Turpio and L. Atilius Prænestinus performed it.
tgt_text.10661: Flaccus, the freedman of Claudius, composed the music to a base and a treble flute.
tgt_text.10662: It is wholly from the Greek, being the Epidicazomenos of Apollodorus.
tgt_text.10663: It was, repre­ sented four times, C. Fannius and M. Valerius being Consuls.
tgt_text.10664: aEMIPHO, the brother of Chremes, has gone abroad, his son Antipho being left at Athens.
tgt_text.10665: Chremes has secretly a wife and a daughter at Lemnos, another wife at Athens, and an only son, who loves a Music-girl.
tgt_text.10666: The mother arrives at Athens from Lemnos.
tgt_text.10668: The girl, her orphan daughter, (Chremes being away,) arranges the funeral.
tgt_text.10669: After Antipho has fallen in love with her when seen there, through the aid of the Parasite he receives her as his wife.
tgt_text.10670: His father and Chremes, having now returned, begin to be enraged.
tgt_text.10671: Afterwards they give thirty minæ to the Parasite, that he may take her as his own wife.
tgt_text.10672: With this money the Music-girl is bought for Phædria.
tgt_text.10673: Antipho then keeps his wife, who has been recognized by his uncle.
tgt_text.10675: cannot withdraw our bard from his pursuits and reduce him to indolence, he endeavours, by invectives, to deter him from writing :
tgt_text.10676: for he is wont to say to this effect,—that the Plays which he has hitherto com­ posed are poor in their language, and of meagre style;
tgt_text.10677: because he has nowhere described a frantic youth as seeing a hind in flight, and the hounds pursuing;
tgt_text.10678: while he implores2 and entreated that he would give her aid.
tgt_text.10679: But if he had been aware that his Play, when formerly first represented, stood its ground more through the merits of the performers than its own, he would attack with much less boldness than he does.
tgt_text.10680: Now, if there is any one who says or thinks to this effect, that if the old Poet had not assailed him first, the young one could have devised no Prologue for him to repeat, without having some one to abuse, let him receive this for an answer:
tgt_text.10681: "that the prize is proposed in common to all who apply to the Dramatic art."
tgt_text.10682: He has aimed at driving our Poet from his studies to absolute want;
tgt_text.10683: he then has intended this for an answer, not an attack.

tgt_text.13054: THE matter which Æsop, the inventor of Fables, has provided, I have polished in Iambic verse.
tgt_text.13055: The advantages of this little work are twofold-that it excites laughter, and by counsel guides the life of man.
tgt_text.13056: But if any one shall think fit to cavil, because not only wild beasts, but even trees speak, let him remember that we are disporting in fables.
tgt_text.13057: Driven by thirst, a Wolf and a Lamb had come to the same stream;
tgt_text.13058: the Wolf stood above, and the Lamb at a dis­ tance below.
tgt_text.13059: Then, the spoiler, prompted by a ravenous maw, alleged a pretext for a quarrel.

tgt_text.13065: The other, disconcerted by the force of truth, exclaimed:

tgt_text.13069: This Fable is applicable to those men who, under false pretences, oppress the innocent.
tgt_text.13070: When Athens1 was flourishing under just laws, liberty grown wanton embroiled the city, and license relaxed the reins of ancient discipline.
tgt_text.13071: Upon this, the partisans of factions conspiring, Pisistratus the Tyrant2 seized the citadel.
tgt_text.13072: When the Athenians were lamenting their sad servitude (not that he was cruel, but because every burden is grievous to those who are unused to it), and began to complain, Æsop related a Fable to the following effect:
tgt_text.13073: —“ The Frogs, roaming at large in their marshy fens, with loud clamour demanded of Jupiter a king, who, by his authority, might check their dissolute manners.
tgt_text.13074: The Father of the Gods smiled, and gave them a little Log, which, on being thrown among them startled the timorous race by the noise and sudden commotion in the bog.
tgt_text.13075: When it had lain for some time immersed in the mud, one of them by chance silently lifted his head above the water, and having taken a peep at the king, called up all the rest.
tgt_text.13076: Having got the better of their fears, vying with each other, they swim towards him, and the insolent mob leap upon the Log.
tgt_text.13077: After defiling it with every kind of insult, they sent to Jupiter, requesting another king, because the one that had been given them was use­ less.
tgt_text.13078: Upon this, he sent them a Water Snake,3 who with his sharp teeth began to gobble them up one after another.
tgt_text.13079: Helpless they strive in vain to escape death;
tgt_text.13081: By stealth, therefore, they send through Mer­ cury a request to Jupiter, to succour them in their distress.
tgt_text.13082: Then said the God in reply :
tgt_text.13084: Since you would not be con­ tent with your good fortune, continue to endure your bad fortune.""
tgt_text.13085: Do you also, 0 fellow-citizens," said Æsop, “ submit to the present evil, lest a greater one befall you.
tgt_text.13086: "That one ought not to plume oneself on the merits which belong to another, but ought rather to pass his life in his own proper guise, Æsop has given us this illustration :
tgt_text.13087: —A Jackdaw, swelling1 with empty pride, picked up some feathers which had fallen from a Peacock, and decked him­ self out therewith;
tgt_text.13088: upon which, despising his own kind, he mingled with a beauteous flock of Peacocks.
tgt_text.13089: They tore his feathers from off the impudent bird, and put him to flight with their beaks.
tgt_text.13090: The Jackdaw, thus roughly handled, in grief hastened to return to his own kind;
tgt_text.13091: repulsed by whom, he had to submit to sad disgrace.
tgt_text.13092: Then said one of those whom he had formerly despised :
tgt_text.13094: If you had been con­ tent with our station, and had been ready to put up with what nature had given, you would neither have experienced the former affront, nor would your ill fortune have had to feel the additional pang of this repulse.
tgt_text.13095: He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
tgt_text.13096: As a Dog, swimming1 through a river, was carrying a piece of meat, he saw his own shadow in the watery mirror ;
tgt_text.13097: and, thinking that it was another booty carried by another dog, attempted to snatch it away;
tgt_text.13098: but his greediness was disap­ pointed, he both dropped the food which he was holding in his mouth, and was after all unable to reach that at which he grasped.
tgt_text.13099: An alliance with the powerful is never to be relied upon:
tgt_text.13100: the present Fable testifies the truth of my maxim.
tgt_text.13101: A Cow, a She-Goat, and a Sheep2 patient under injuries, were partners in the forests with a Lion.
tgt_text.13102: When they had captured a Stag of vast bulk, thus spoke the Lion, after it had been divided into shares :
tgt_text.13104: Because my name is Lion, I take the first;
tgt_text.13105: the second you will yield to me because I am courageous;
tgt_text.13106: then, because I am the strongest,3 the third will fall to my lot;
tgt_text.13107: if any one touches the fourth, woe betide him.
tgt_text.13108: "Thus .did unscrupulousness seize upon the whole prey for itself.
tgt_text.13109: Æsop, on seeing the pompous wedding of a thief, who was his neighbour, immediately began to relate the following .
tgt_text.13111: Once on a time, when the Sun was thinking of taking a wife,1 the Frogs sent forth their clamour to the stars.
tgt_text.13112: Dis­ turbed by their croakings, Jupiter asked the cause of their complaints.
tgt_text.13113: Then said one of the inhabitants of the pool:
tgt_text.13114: " As it is, by himself he parches up all the standing waters, and compels us unfortunates to languish and die in our scorched abode.
tgt_text.13115: What is to become of us, if he beget children r "A Fox, by chance, casting his eyes on a Tragic Mask:
tgt_text.13116: "Ah," said she, “great as is its beauty, still it has no brains.”
tgt_text.13117: 2This is meant for those to whom fortune has granted honor and renown, leaving them void of common sense.

tgt_text.13125: A Sparrow upbraided a Hare, that had been pounced upon by an Eagle, and was sending forth piercing cries.

tgt_text.13131: "Whoever has once become notorious by base fraud, even if he speaks the truth, gains no belief.

tgt_text.13149: This story shows that what you contemn is often found of more utility than what you load with praises.
tgt_text.13150: A Stag, when he had drunk at a stream, stood still, and gazed upon his likeness in the water.

tgt_text.13152: Then a wood received the beast;

tgt_text.13156: Oh, how unhappy am I, who now too late find out how useful to me were the things that I despised ;
tgt_text.13157: and what sor­ row the things I used to praise, have caused me.
tgt_text.13158: "He who is delighted at being flattered with artful words, generally pays the ignominious penalty of a late repentance.
tgt_text.13159: As a Raven, perched in a lofty tree, was about to eat a piece of cheese, stolen from a window,1 a Fox espied him, and thereupon began thus to speak :
tgt_text.13161: 0 Raven, what a glossiness there is upon those feathers of yours !
tgt_text.13162: What grace you curry in your shape and air!
tgt_text.13163: If you had a voice, no bird whatever would be superior to you."
tgt_text.13164: On this, the other, while, in his folly, attempting to show off his voice, let fall the cheese from his mouth, which the crafty Fox with greedy teeth instantly snatched up.
tgt_text.13165: Then, too late, the Raven, thus, in his stupidity overreached, heaved a bitter sigh.
tgt_text.13166: By this story 2 it is shown, how much ingenuity avails, and how wisdom is always an overmatch for strength.
tgt_text.13167: A bungling Cobbler, broken down by want, having begun to practise physic in a strange place, and selling his anti­ dote1 under a feigned name, gained some reputation for himself by his delusive speeches.
tgt_text.13168: Upon this, the King of the city, who lay ill, being afflicted with a severe malady, asked for a cup, for the purpose of try­ ing him;
tgt_text.13169: and then pouring water into it, and pretending that he was mixing poison with the fellow's antidote, ordered him to drink it off, in consideration of a stated rewar Through fear of death, the cobbler then confessed that not by any skill in the medical art, but through the stupidity of the public, he had gained his reputation.
tgt_text.13170: The King, hav­ ing summoned a council, thus remarked :
tgt_text.13172: What think you of the extent of your madness, when you do not hesitate to trust your lives2 to one to whom no one would trust his feet to be fitted with shoes ?
tgt_text.13173: "This, I should say with good reason, is aimed at those through whose folly impudence makes a profit.
tgt_text.13174: In a change of government, the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.
tgt_text.13175: That this is the fact this little Fable shows.
tgt_text.13176: A timorous Old Man was feeding an Ass n a meadow.
tgt_text.13177: Frightened by a sudden alarm of the enemy, he tried to per­ suade the Ass to fly, lest they should be taken prisoners.
tgt_text.13179: “ Pray, do you suppose that the conqueror will place double panniers upon me ?” The Old Man said, “ No.“
tgt_text.13180: Then what matters it to me, so long as I have to carry my panniers, whom I serveWhen a rogue offers his name as surety in a doubtful case, he has no design to act straight-forwardly, but is looking to mischief.
tgt_text.13182: Stag asked a Sheep for a measure1 of wheat, a Wolf being his surety.

tgt_text.13185: you, of rushing out of sight with rapid flight:
tgt_text.13186: where am I to look for you both when the day comes ?

tgt_text.13190: a Wolf, summoned as a witness, affirmed that not only one was owing but ten.

tgt_text.13192: A few days after, the Sheep saw the Wolf lying in a pit. “ This," said she, " is the reward of villany, sent by the Gods.
tgt_text.13193: "No one returns with good will to the place which has done him a mischief..
tgt_text.13194: Her months completed,1 a Woman in labour lay upon the ground, uttering woful moans.
tgt_text.13195: Her Husband entreated her to lay her body on the bed, where she might with more ease deposit her ripe burden. " I feel far from confident," said she, “ that my pains can end in the place where they originated.
tgt_text.13196: ”The fair words of a wicked man are fraught with treachery, and the subjoined lines warn us to shun them.
tgt_text.13198: Bitch, ready to whelp,2 having entreated another that she might give birth to her offspring in her kennel, easily obtained the favour.
tgt_text.13199: Afterwards, on the other asking for her place back again, she renewed her entreaties, earnestly begging for a short time, until she might be enabled to lead forth her whelps when they had gained sufficient strength.
tgt_text.13200: This time being also expired, the other began more urgently to press for her abode :
tgt_text.13201: "If," said the tenant, "you can be a match for me and my litter, I will depart from the place.
tgt_text.13202: ”An ill-judged project is not only without effect, but also lures mortals to their destruction.
tgt_text.13203: Some Dogs espied a raw hide sunk in a river.
tgt_text.13204: In order that they might more easily get it out and devour it, they fell to drinking up the water;
tgt_text.13205: they burst, however, and perished before they could reach what they sought.
tgt_text.13206: Whoever has fallen from a previous high estate, is in his calamity the butt even of cowards.
tgt_text.13207: As a Lion, worn out with years, and deserted by his strength, lay drawing his last breath, a Wild Boar came up to him, with flashing tusks,1 and with a blow revenged an old affront.
tgt_text.13208: Next, with hostile horns, a Bull pierced the body of his foe.
tgt_text.13209: An Ass, on seeing the wild beast maltreated with impunity, tore up his forehead with his heels.

tgt_text.13212: but in being inevitably forced to bear with you, disgrace to nature!
tgt_text.13213: I seem to die a double death."A Weasel, on being caught by a Man, wishing to escape impending death :
tgt_text.13214: " Pray," said she, " do spare me, for 'tis I who keep your house clear of troublesome mice."

tgt_text.13218: " and so saying, he put the wicked creature to death.
tgt_text.13219: Those persons ought to recognize this as applicable to themselves, whose object is private advantage, and who boast to the unthinking of an unreal merit.
tgt_text.13220: The man who becomes liberal all of a sudden, gratifies the foolish, but for the wary spreads his toils in vain.
tgt_text.13222: Thief one night threw a crust of bread to a Dog, to try whether he could be gained by the proffered victuals:
tgt_text.13223: " Hark you," said the Dog, " do you think to stop my tongue so that I may not bark for my master's property ?
tgt_text.13225: For this sudden liberality bids me be on the watch, that you may not profit by my neglect.
tgt_text.13226: The needy man, while affecting to imitate the powerful, comes to ruin.
tgt_text.13227: Once on a time, a Frog espied an Ox in a meadow, and moved with envy at his vast bulk, puffed out her wrinkled skin, and then asked her young ones whether she was bigger than the Ox.
tgt_text.13228: They said "No." Again, with still greater efforts, she distended her skin, and in like manner enquired which was the bigger:
tgt_text.13231: At last, while, full of indignation, she tried, with all her might, to puff herself out, she burst her body on the spot.
tgt_text.13232: Those who give bad advice to discreet persons, both lose their pains, and are laughed to scorn.
tgt_text.13233: It has been related,1 that Dogs drink at the river Nile running along, that they may not be seized by the Crocodiles.
tgt_text.13234: Accordingly, a Dog having begun to drink while running along, a Crocodile thus addressed him :
tgt_text.13235: " Lap as leisurely as you like;
tgt_text.13237: come nearer, and don't be afraid," said he.
tgt_text.13239: “Egad, I would do so with all my heart, did I not know that you are eager for my flesh."
tgt_text.13240: Harm should be done to no man;
tgt_text.13241: but if any one do an injury, this Fable shows that be may be visited with a like return.
tgt_text.13243: Fox is said to have given a Stork the first invitation to a banquet, and to have placed before her some thin broth in a flat dish, of which the hungry Stork could in no way get a taste.

tgt_text.13529: A certain married Man, who was very fond of his Wife, having now provided the white toga2 for his Son, was pri­ vately taken aside by his Freedman, who hoped that he should be substituted as his next heir, and who, after telling many lies about the youth, and still more about the mis­ conduct of the chaste Wife, added, what he knew would espe­ cially grieve one so fond, that a gallant was in the habit of paying her visits, and that the honor of his house was stained with base adultery.

tgt_text.13795: A ship which had been tossed by a fierce tempest (while the passengers were all in tears, and filled with apprehensions of death) on the day suddenly changing to a serene aspect, began to be borne along in safety upon the buoyant waves, and to inspire the mariners with an excess of gladness.
tgt_text.13796: On this, the Pilot, who had been rendered wise by experience, remarked:
tgt_text.13797: "We ought to be moderate in our joy, and to complain with caution;
tgt_text.13798: for the whole of life is a mixture of grief and joy.
tgt_text.13799: "The Dogs once sent1 Ambassadors to Jupiter, to entreat of him a happier lot in life, and that he would deliver them from the insulting treatment of man, who gave them bread mixed with bran, and satisfied their most urgent hunger with filthy offal.
tgt_text.13800: The ambassadors set out, but with no hasty steps, while snuffing with their nostrils for food in every filth.
tgt_text.13801: Being summoned, they fail to make their appearance.
tgt_text.13802: After some difficulty Mercury finds them at last, and brings them up in confusion.
tgt_text.13803: As soon, however, as they saw the coun­ tenance of mighty Jove, in their fright they bewrayed the whole palace.
tgt_text.13804: Out they go, driven away with sticks;
tgt_text.13806: great Jove forbade that they should be sent back.
tgt_text.13808: their Ambassadors did not return, and suspecting that they had committed something dis­ graceful, after a while ordered others to be appointed to aid them.
tgt_text.13809: Rumour soon betrayed the former Ambassadors.
tgt_text.13810: Dreading that something of a similar nature may happen a second time, they stuff the Dogs behind with perfumes, and plenty of them.
tgt_text.13813: at ohce they take their departure.
tgt_text.13814: They beg for an audience, and forthwith obtain it.
tgt_text.13815: Then did the most mighty Father of the Gods take his seat on his throne, and brandish his thunders;
tgt_text.13817: The Dogs in alarm, so sudden was the crash, in a moment let fall the perfumes with their dung.
tgt_text.13818: All cry out, that the affront must be avenged.
tgt_text.13819: But before proceeding to punish­ ment, thus spoke Jupiter:
tgt_text.13820: —" It is not for a King to send Ambassadors away, nor is it a difficult matter to inflict a proper punishment on the offence;
tgt_text.13821: but by way of judgment this is the reward you shall have.
tgt_text.13822: I don't forbid their return, but they shall be famished with hunger, lest they be not able to keep their stomachs in order..
tgt_text.13823: And as for those who sent such despicable Ambassadors as you, they shall never be free from the insults of man.
tgt_text.13824: "And so it is,1 that even now the Dogs of the present day are in expectation of their Ambassadors.
tgt_text.13825: When one of them sees a strange Dog appear, he snuffs at his tail.
tgt_text.13826: He who gives relief to the wicked has to repent it before long.

tgt_text.13828: for when she had recovered, she instantly killed the MaID.
tgt_text.13829: On another one asking her the reason of this crime, she made answer:
tgt_text.13830: " That people may learn not to assist the wicked.
tgt_text.13831: 1While a Fox, digging a lair, was throwing out the earth, and making deeper and more numerous burrows, she came to the farthest recesses of a Dragon's den, who was watching some treasure hidden there.
tgt_text.13832: As soon as the Fox perceived him, she began:

tgt_text.13834: and next, as you see clearly enough that gold is not suited to my mode of life, have the goodness to answer me :
tgt_text.13835: what profit do you derive from this toil, or what is the reward, so great that you should be deprived of sleep, and pass your life in darkness ?" " None at all," replied the other;
tgt_text.13836: "but this task has been assigned me by supreme Jove." "
tgt_text.13837: Then you neither take anything for yourself, nor give to another "
tgt_text.13838: Such is the. will of the Fates." " Don't be angry then, if I say frankly :

tgt_text.13840: "As you must go to that place to which others have gone before, why in the blindness of your mind do you torment your wretched existence ?

tgt_text.13855: Simonides, who wrote such excellent lyric poems, the more easily to support his poverty, began to make a tour of the celebrated cities of Asia, singing the praises of victors for such reward as he might receive.
tgt_text.13856: After he had become enriched by this kind of gain, he resolved to return to his native land by sea;
tgt_text.13857: (for he was born, it is said, in the island of Ceos1).
tgt_text.13858: Accordingly he embarked in a ship, which a dreadful tempest, together with its own rottenness, caused to founder at sea.

tgt_text.13879: An Ant and a Fly were contending with great warmth which was of the greater importance.
tgt_text.13880: The Fly was the first to begin :
tgt_text.13882: Can you possibly compare with my endow­ ments ?
tgt_text.13883: When a sacrifice is made, I am the first to taste of the entrails that belong to the Gods.
tgt_text.13884: I pass my time among the altars, I wander through all the temples;
tgt_text.13885: soon as I have espied it, I seat myself on the head of a king;
tgt_text.13886: and I taste of the chaste kisses of matrons.
tgt_text.13887: I labour not, and yet enjoy the nicest of things:
tgt_text.13888: what like to this, good rustic, falls to your lot ?" " Eating with the Gods," said the Ant, " is certainly a thing to be boasted of;
tgt_text.13889: but by him who is invited, not him who is loathed as an intruder.
tgt_text.13890: You talk about kings and the kisses of matrons.
tgt_text.13891: While I am carefully heaping up a stock of grain for winter, I see you feeding on filth about the walls.

tgt_text.13895: therefore it is that you have nothing when you stand in need of it.
tgt_text.13896: And, further, you boast about what modesty ought to conceal.
tgt_text.13898: when winter comes you are silent.
tgt_text.13899: While the cold is shrivelling you up and putting you to death, a well-stored abode harbours me.
tgt_text.13900: Surely I have now pulled down your pride enough."
tgt_text.13901: A Fable of this nature distinctly points out the characters of those who set themselves off with unfounded praises, and of those whose virtues gain solid fame.
tgt_text.13902: I have said, above, how greatly learning is esteemed among men:
tgt_text.13903: I will now hand down to posterity how great is the honor paid to it by the Gods.
tgt_text.13904: Simonides, the very same of whom I have before made mention, agreed, at a fixed price, to write a panegyric for a certain Pugilist, 1 who had been victorious:
tgt_text.13906: As the meagreness of his subject cramped his imagination, he used, according to general custom, the license of the Poet, and introduced the twin stars of Leda,2 citing them as an example of similar honours.
tgt_text.13907: He finished the Poem according to contract, but received only a third part of the sum agreed upon.

tgt_text.13911: Although defrauded, and smarting under the injury, in order that he might not, by parting on bad terms, break off all friendly intercourse, he promised that he would.
tgt_text.13912: At the hour named he returned, and took his place at table.
tgt_text.13913: The banquet shone joyously with its cups;
tgt_text.13914: the house re­ sounded with gladness, amid vast preparations, when, on a sudden, two young men, covered with dust, and dripping with perspiration, their bodies of more than human form, requested one of the servants to call Simonides to them, and say that it was of consequence to him to make no delay.

tgt_text.14101: A Person had recited2 some worthless composition to Æsop, in which he had inordinately bragged about himself.

tgt_text.14108: A Soldier of Pompeius Magnus, a man of huge bulk, by talking mincingly and walking with an affected gait, had acquired the character of an effeminate wretch, and that most fully established.
tgt_text.14109: Lying in wait by night for the beasts of burden of his General, he drives away the mules laden with garments and gold, and a vast weight of silver.

tgt_text.14112: On this, Magnus says to him :

tgt_text.14119: Then Magnus, a man of easy disposition, orders the false accusers to be sent about their business,1 and will not believe the man guilty of so great audacity.
tgt_text.14120: Not long afterwards a barbarian, confiding in his strength of hand, challenges one of the Romans.

tgt_text.14130: When Juno1 was praising her own chastity, Venus did not lose the opportunity of a joke, and, to show that there was no female equal to herself in that virtue, is said to have asked this question of the Hen :
tgt_text.14132: Tell me, will you, with how much food could you be satisfied ?"
tgt_text.14134: "Whatever you give me will be enough;
tgt_text.14135: but still you must let me scratch a bit with my feet."
tgt_text.14136: "To keep you from scratching," said the Goddess, " is a measure of wheat enough ?"
tgt_text.14139: but still do allow me to scratch." "

tgt_text.14141: Then at last the hen confessed the weak point in her nature :
tgt_text.14142: "Though a whole barn were open for me, still scratch I must."

tgt_text.14242: A Man while going through the fields along his solitary path, heard the word "Hail!" whereat he stopped for a moment, but seeing no one, went on his way.

tgt_text.14246: Then, perceiving that he had been deluded :

tgt_text.14355: "This Fable is written for those Women who unite them­ selves to ignorant and foolish Men.A City Mouse being once entertained at the table of a Country one, dined on humble acorns in a hole.

tgt_text.14359: while the unfortunate Rustic, all trepidation in that strange house, and dreading death, runs to-and-fro along the walls.
